revision.comment: Removed 'caused by alcoholism'. Was a friend of Sean's and this is an assumption, without his consent.
revision.text:
{{other people|Sean Hughes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Sean Hughes | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = John Hughes | birth_date = 10 November 1965 | birth_place = [[Archway, London]], England | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2017|10|16|1965|11|10}} | death_place = Archway, London, England | occupation = Comedian, writer, actor }} '''Sean Hughes''' (10 November 1965 – 16 October 2017) was an English-born Irish [[stand-up comedian]], [[writer]] and [[actor]]. He starred in his own [[Channel 4]] television show ''[[Sean's Show]]'' and was one of the regular team captains on the [[BBC Two]] musical panel game ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]''. ==Early life== Hughes was born in [[Archway, London]], but spent most of his youth in [[Firhouse]], [[Dublin]]. His mother, who was from [[Cork (city)|Cork]] met his father, who was from Dublin, on a London bus. His mother intended to train as a nurse but the plan never materialised. His father worked in a [[telephone exchange]] and was also a [[driving instructor]]. At the age of six Hughes moved to Dublin and lived with his paternal grandmother.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/apr/24/sean-hughes-my-family-values|title=Sean Hughes: My family values|first=Interview by Nikki|last=Spencer|date=24 April 2015|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2017|via=www.theguardian.com}} He attended [[Coláiste Éanna]] in [[Ballyroan, Dublin|Ballyroan]]. Writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[Bruce Dessau]] noted of Hughes's early years that:
[He] used to talk about how sounding like a [[Cockney]] in an Irish school was not easy. He later quipped that he spent "most of my childhood in a headlock". Not surprisingly his [[Mary Poppins]] accent soon developed a lilting local burr. Making schoolfriends laugh was a classic defence mechanism and he even set up comedy gigs at his school. What started out as a hobby quickly became a career.{{cite news |last= Dessau |first= Bruce | authorlink= Bruce Dessau |title= Sean Hughes obituary |url= https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2017/oct/16/sean-hughes-obituary| date= 16 October 2017 |newspaper= [[The Guardian]] |location=London| accessdate=16 October 2017 }}
==Career== In 1987 he began appearing at the [[The Comedy Store, London|Comedy Store]]. In 1990, aged 24, he became the youngest winner of the prestigious [[Perrier Comedy Award]] for his show, ''A One-Night Stand with Sean Hughes''.{{cite web|url=http://www.comedyawards.co.uk/best-comedy-show/1990/sean-hughes|website=lastminute.com|title=sean hughes - a one night stand|accessdate=16 October 2017}} He marked his 30th birthday with the ''Sean Hughes Is Thirty Somehow'' tour, which was broadcast on [[Channel 4]], in 1995. Hughes returned to stand-up, touring the UK and Australia in 2007 with his show, ''The Right Side of Wrong''.{{cite web|title=Mick Perrin for Just for Laughs Live in Association with PBJ Management and Gilded Balloon Productions presents Sean Hughes: The Right Side of Wrong|url=http://www.gildedballoon.co.uk/2007/press_releases/Sean_Hughes_~The_Right_Side_of_Wrong~.pdf|publisher=Gilded Balloon Teviot|accessdate=9 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080529124109/http://www.gildedballoon.co.uk/2007/press_releases/Sean_Hughes_~The_Right_Side_of_Wrong~.pdf|archivedate=29 May 2008}} As well as comedy, he wrote collections of prose and poetry and worked on a number of films. He also presented weekend radio shows on the BBC's London radio station [[BBC GLR]], and in 2002 joined [[BBC Radio 6 Music|BBC 6 Music]], presenting the Sunday morning programme. He left the station a year after its launch, proclaiming it had turned into everything he had wanted it to be. He also wrote two novels, ''The Detainees'' (1998) and ''It's What He Would Have Wanted'' (2000).{{cite web|title=Sean's novel take on life|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/453686.stm|website=BBC News|accessdate=16 October 2017}} It was reported that Hughes was a close friend of the late American comedian [[Bill Hicks]], but Hughes stated this was not true. In a 2014 interview, he explained, "It says on my Wikipedia page that I was good friends with him. I wasn't! We were in Australia together, so we hung out. I did get to know him a little bit, which was a real pleasure. When I saw him I just went, 'That's the best comic I'm going to see in my lifetime.'"{{Cite news|title=Stand-up countdown Sean Hughes|first=Ben|last=Williams|work=Time Out|date=25 March 2014|quote=It says on my Wikipedia page that I was good friends with him. I wasn't! We were in Australia together, so we hung out. I did get to know him a little bit, which was a real pleasure. When I saw him I just went, "That's the best comic I'm going to see in my lifetime."|location=London}} Nevertheless, Hughes wrote the foreword to [[Cynthia True]]'s biography of Hicks, ''American Scream. The Bill Hicks Story''. He concluded his foreword by writing "being a genius is a heavy burden and he's the only one I'm ever likely to meet. I still miss you Bill."[http://dir.salon.com/story/people/feature/2002/03/13/hicks/index3.html "American Scream: The Bill Hicks Story"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080503192601/http://dir.salon.com/story/people/feature/2002/03/13/hicks/index3.html|date=3 May 2008}}, salon.com; retrieved 29 April 2008. ==Film and television drama== Hughes had a small role in the film ''[[The Commitments (film)|The Commitments]]'' (1991), playing a record producer.{{Cite web|url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/commitments-1991|title=THE COMMITMENTS {{!}} British Board of Film Classification|last=|first=|date=17 March 2016|website=bbfc.co.uk|access-date=16 October 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/movies/the-commitments/cast/128735/|title=The Commitments Cast and Crew|website=TVGuide.com|access-date=16 October 2017}} In 1992, he had his own TV show, ''[[Sean's Show]]'', ostensibly set in his own home. It received a nomination for the 1992 British Comedy Award for Best Channel 4 Sitcom.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/seans-show/|title=Sean's Show|last=TV.com|website=TV.com|access-date=16 October 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/blogs/poplife/2013/01/25/sean-hughes-once-i-embraced-my-gene-pool-i-found-life-much-more-bearable/|title=Sean Hughes: ‘Once I embraced my gene pool I found life much more bearable’ {{!}} Pop Life|last=Mullally|first=Una|date=25 January 2013|website=www.irishtimes.com|language=en|access-date=16 October 2017}} Series one of ''Sean's Show'' has been released on DVD. Later, he recorded a series of brief programmes called ''Sean's Shorts'', in which he toured England, visiting many of the country's towns and cities, visiting local places of interest and meeting local people.{{cite web|title=Comedian Sean Hughes comes to The Old Town Hall in Hemel Hempstead with his brand new show, Penguins|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/leisure/comedy/11484489.Sean_Hughes_picks_up_a_p___p___p___penguin/?ref=ec|website=Watford Observer|accessdate=16 October 2017}} He appeared in the film ''Snakes and Ladders'' shot in Dublin, and released in 1996.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/1996/film/reviews/snakes-and-ladders-1200447191|title=Snakes and Ladders|last=Levy|first=Emanuel|date=21 October 1996|work=Variety|access-date=16 October 2017}} From 1996 to 2002, he was a team captain on the [[BBC 2]] comedy quiz show ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'', alongside [[Phill Jupitus]] and [[Mark Lamarr]].{{cite web|title=Sean Hughes quits Buzzcocks|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/2166693.stm|website=BBC News|accessdate=16 October 2017}} He can be seen during [[Terrorvision]]'s music video for their single "Tequila" from 1999 {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZC4aC8LLsvw&feature=channel_video_title|title=Never Mind the Buzzcocks episode showing Sean in Terrorvision video|accessdate=11 January 2012}} and in the video for [[The Cure]]'s 1996 single, "[[The 13th]]".{{cite news|url=http://www.musicfanclubs.org/cure/press/I53.html|title=Making Wild Mood Swings pay off|publisher=Music Fan Club|date=22 April 1996|accessdate=16 October 2017}} He appeared in the 2010 [[Edinburgh Fringe]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-11053202|title=BBC News - Fringe's funniest joke prize awarded to Tim Vine|publisher=bbc.co.uk|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=21 September 2010}} In ITV's series ''[[The Last Detective]]'', featuring [[Dangerous Davies|"Dangerous" Davies]], Hughes played his friend, the perpetually unemployed and well-read "Mod Lewis" (he spends all his time at the library to save on heating).{{Cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2009/02/---page-margin.html|title=DVD reviews: 'George Gently' and 'The Last Detective', British mysteries never broadcast in the U.S.|date=18 February 2009|website=LA Times Blogs - Show Tracker|access-date=16 October 2017}} He played [[Eileen Grimshaw]]'s love interest Pat in the British soap ''[[Coronation Street]]''.[http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/a46680/sean-hughes-joins-corrie-cast.html "Sean Hughes joins Corrie cast"], Digitalspy.co.uk, 16 May 2007. In 2000, Hughes voiced the part of Finbar the [[clockwork]] [[Shark]], one of seven plastic bath toys which come to life whenever no-one is watching in the [[children's television series]] ''[[Rubbadubbers]]'', shown on [[CBeebies]] in the [[United Kingdom]] for pre-school children.{{cite web|title=RUBBADUBBERS - SCARY FINBAR|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/rubbadubbers-scary-finbar-video|website=bbfc.co.uk|accessdate=16 October 2017}} He played Sergeant Lake in the ITV [[Agatha Christie's Marple]] production of ''[[They Do It with Mirrors]]'', which was broadcast on 1 January 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/presspacks/agathachristiemarpletheydoitwithmirrors/default.html|title=Agatha Christie Marple They Do It With Mirrors|publisher=Itv.com|accessdate=21 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106070319/http://www.itv.com/presscentre/presspacks/agathachristiemarpletheydoitwithmirrors/default.html|archivedate=6 January 2011|df=dmy-all}} Hughes played Brendan in the film version of [[Tony Hawks]]' book, [[Round Ireland with a Fridge (film)|''Round Ireland with a Fridge'']] (2010).{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01dpnx5|title=Round Ireland with a Fridge - BBC Four|website=BBC|access-date=16 October 2017}} He also played the lead in the film adaptation of [[Spike Milligan]]'s comic novel, ''[[Puckoon]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.guerilla-films.com/puckoon/cast.htm|title=Spike Milligan's Puckoon: Cast|website=www.guerilla-films.com|access-date=16 October 2017}} Hughes also voiced Tapir in the three ''[[Robbie the Reindeer]]'' films.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2002/11_november/26/robbie_reindeer.pdf|title=Robbie The Reindeer in Legend Of The Lost Tribe Press Pack|date=Christmas 2002|website=BBC Press Office|publisher=BBC|page=3|format=PDF|access-date=16 October 2017}} He appeared in ''[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]'' in 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06t1vkc|title=Home for Christmas, Series 30, Casualty - BBC One|website=BBC|access-date=16 October 2017}} ==Stage and online== In November 2013, Hughes started a [[podcast]] called "Under The Radar with DogsInTheField Productions"/Acast.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/sean-hughes-off-the-radar/id739680686?mt=2|title=iTunes|accessdate=16 October 2017}} Hughes took over the role of [[Station master|Stationmaster]] Mr Perks in the musical ''[[The Railway Children]]'' at King's Cross Theatre in March 2015.{{cite news| url=https://www.londonboxoffice.co.uk/news/post/sean-hughes-railway-children|location=London, UK|work=London Box Office|first=Oliver|last=Mitford|title=Comedian Sean Hughes joins ''The Railway Children''|date=23 February 2015}} ==Death== Hughes died at the age of 51 on 16 October 2017 from the effects of [[cirrhosis]],'Sean Hughes' funeral moving and complex ...', 'The Irish Times', 14 October 2017. at [[Whittington Hospital]] in North London (the same hospital in which he was born in 1965).{{cite news|title=Comedian Sean Hughes dies aged 51|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-41632761|work=BBC News|date=11 October 2017}}{{cite web|title=Sean Hughes: Liver cirrhosis kills Irish stand-up comedian aged 51|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/sean-hughes-liver-cirrhosis-kills-irish-stand-comedian-aged-51-1643321|website=www.ibtimes.co.uk|accessdate=16 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/oct/16/sean-hughes-comedian-dies-aged-51|title=Sean Hughes: comedian dies aged 51|first1=Jamie|last1=Grierson|first2=Chris|last2=Wiegand|date=16 October 2017|publisher=theguardian.com|accessdate=16 June 2018}} A funeral service was held at [[St Pancras and Islington Cemetery|Islington & St. Pancras Cemetery]] on 23 October 2017, where, after the mourning party heard eulogies to his memory, listened to recited extracts of some of Hughes' poetry and recorded music from ''[[The Smiths]]'', his body was cremated. A [[wake (ceremony)|wake]] being held afterwards in a [[public house|pub]] in the vicinity.[https://www.irishnews.com/magazine/entertainment/2017/10/24/news/sean-hughes-funeral-moving-and-complex-says-david-baddiel-1170289 "Sean Hughes' funeral moving and complex"], ''The Irish News'', 24 October 2017. ==Works== ===Shows=== *''Mumbo Jumbo'' {{Cite web|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/leisure/comedy/13715804.How_to_annoy_Sean_Hughes|title=How to annoy Sean Hughes|last=Enfield|first=Laura|website=Watford Observer|language=en|access-date=16 October 2017}} *''Penguins'' {{Cite web|url=https://www.exeterphoenix.org.uk/events/sean-hughes-penguins|title=Sean Hughes – Penguins|website=www.exeterphoenix.org.uk|access-date=16 October 2017}} *''Life Becomes Noises'' *''Ducks and Other Mistakes I've Made'' {{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2010/aug/08/my-edinburgh-laura-solon|title=Laura Solon: My Edinburgh|last=Solon|first=Laura|date=8 August 2010|work=The Guardian|access-date=16 October 2017|issn=0261-3077}} *''What I Meant to Say Was...'' {{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/devon/low/people_and_places/arts_and_culture/newsid_8414000/8414696.stm|title=City is having a laugh|last=Laing|first=Jemima|date=16 December 2009|work=BBC Devon|access-date=16 October 2017}} *''The Right Side of Wrong'' {{Cite web|url=http://www.uktw.co.uk/archive/comedy/sean-hughes/the-right-side-of-wrong/L218770053/|title=Archive for Sean Hughes - The Right Side of Wrong at Pavilion Theatre, Bournemouth. 2007. [COMEDY]|website=UK Theatre Web|access-date=16 October 2017}} *''Live... And Seriously Funny'' {{Cite web|url=https://riversideparramatta.com.au/show/sean-hughes|title=Sean Hughes » Riverside Parramatta|website=riversideparramatta.com.au|access-date=16 October 2017}} *''A One Night Stand with Sean Hughes'' {{Cite web|url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/latest-news/article/item273620/sean-hughes-joins-railway-children|title=Sean Hughes joins Railway Children|website=www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk|access-date=16 October 2017}} ===Books=== *''Sean's Book'' (1993) {{ISBN|978-1857931457}} *''The Grey Area'' (1995) {{ISBN|978-1857934656}} *''The Detainees'' (1998) {{ISBN|978-0684820811}} *''It's What He Would Have Wanted'' (2000) {{ISBN|978-0743201599}} *''My Struggle to Be Decent and Poems of Sadness and Light'' {{ISBN|978-1908067098}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.poetry-festival.co.uk/podcast/04-sean-hughes-poetry-stand|title=Sean Hughes Poetry and Stand-up|publisher=poetry-festival.co.uk|access-date=16 October 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.seanhughes.co.uk}} * [http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2bab5438c8 Sean Hughes] at the [[British Film Institute]] * [http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/s/689/sean_hughes Sean Hughes] on [[Chortle]] * {{IMDb name|id=0400923|name=Sean Hughes}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hughes, Sean (Comedian)}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Alcohol-related deaths in England]] [[Category:Deaths from cirrhosis]] [[Category:Disease-related deaths in England]] [[Category:English people of Irish descent]] [[Category:English male comedians]] [[Category:English male television actors]] [[Category:Irish male comedians]] [[Category:Irish male television actors]] [[Category:Male actors from London]] [[Category:People from Archway, London]] [[Category:People from County Dublin]]
